Title: Notes on the diet and ingestion of plastic material by the Magellanic Penguin Spheniscus magellanicus on Santa Catarina Island and mainland (Brazil)

Obs: Latitude and longitude placed in the midle of the offshore coast of Florianopolis Island.

Author: Argel de Oliveira
Title: O ninhal do Parque Estadual das Fontes do Ipiranga, Sao Paulo (estado de Sao Paulo, Brasil)
Journal_Unpub: Boletim do Centro de Estudos Ornitologicos

Author: Sick
Title: Ornitologia Brasileira
Obs: The author only mention plastic interaction specifically for ‘Puffinus puffinus’ (p. 179), but he also report –on this same page-- other procellariiform species that were affected by plastics. However, as he does not name specifically those species (with positive plastic interaction), we did not include them on the ‘taxonomic’ account -- only ‘Puffinus puffinus’ and its higher-level taxonomic ranks (on both ‘_analysed’ and ‘_with_plastic’). The author also does not specify a place from the mentioned States where the samples were obtained; therefore we did not include it on the map.  *Check: Costalunga & Chiarardia 1988 Congres Bras Zoo.

Author: Schulz-Neto
Title: Aspectos biologicos da avifauna marinha na Reserva Biologica do Atol das Rocas, Rio Grande do Norte, Brasil

Title: Food habits of the, Royal Albatross, Diomedea epomophora (Lesson, 1825), at the seacoast of Brazil

Author: Olmos & Silva e Silva
Title: Breeding biology of the Little Blue Heron (Egretta caerulea) in southeastern Brazil
Obs: The authors mention the use of the ‘pink vinyl tape’ (used for marking the Little Blue Heron nests) as a nest material by another species on the same colony, the Scarlet Ibises (Eudocimus ruber). As the paper is about the Little Blue Herons, here on the index sheet we accounted for just one species, although in both “_analysed” and “_with_plastic” sheets we included the Scarlet Ibis as well.

Author: Petry & Fonseca
Title: Effects of human activities in the marine environment on seabirds along the coast of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil
Obs: We did not consider 'Thalassarche chrysostoma' an analyzed species, as it was latter reidentified as 'Thalassarche chlororhynchos' (L. Bugoni, pers. comm.). The authors mention types of anthropogenic material found. SampleSize is based on the stomach contents analyzed. Note that n=2 ‘Diomedea epomophora’ are the same reported herein under “ID 6” (Petry et al 2001).

Title: Reproducao de Sterna hirundinacea Lesson e S. eurygnatha Saunders (Aves, Laridae), no litoral de Santa Catarina, Brasil

Obs: Data based on the information provided in the Abstract, because in the main text it is not specified which species were analysed, how many birds per species, and if there was some categorization of the plastics. Accordingly, we did not compute the ‘taxonomy’ information (for neither “_analysed” and “_with_plastics”).

Title: Registros de Pinguins-de-Magalhaes (Spheniscus magellanicus) mortos no Rio Grande so Sul
Obs: SampleSize = number of stomach contents analysed. The authors report some possible ‘entanglements’, but without much information related is not reliable assume that it was not fishermen on the coast that made it post-mortem (a common practice in the region for getting sandworms used as bait).

The authors presented the DataAnalysis per cavities of the gastrointestinal tract.

Journal_Unpub: Book chapter – in Mohr et al. (orgs.)
Obs: SampleSize = number of stomach contents analysed. Altough authors mention ‘nylon of various colors’ and ‘plastic pieces of c. 2x1mm’ size, these information are incomplete, lacking tangible numbers, and therefore we considered it as a “Mention”. However, we did consider as if they had presented “FO”, because they give the raw numbers within the text (29 / 99 = 29.3%).

Author: Colabuono et al.

Obs: Latitude and Longitude placed besides the PARNA Lagoa do Peixe, as a mid-point between 29° and 33°S  mentioned by the authors; as they did not mention locations of the bycatch specimens we just considered the coastline.  MonthsSampled = number of years*12. As authors mention the range from Size and Mass, we consider them as valuable information. Article based on the chapter 3 of F.I. Colabuono’ PhD thesis.

Author: Colabuono et al.

Obs: MonthsSampled = 31, accounting for 31 beach surveys (authors did not mention the periodicity of surveys); SampleSize = just the dead birds necropsied. Altough the authors present the ‘maximum size’ of fragments, Size was not included in our criteria, as they do not present ‘range’ or some other measurent of variability.

Author: Tourinho et al.
Title: Is marine debris ingestion still a problem for the coastal marine biota of southern Brazil
Obs: Authors presented the DataAnalysis(Col), based on the total amount of itens per colour, and not separated by species. We have located their study area centroid in the mouth of the Lagoa dos Patos.

Obs: Authors describe fishing attempts from Common Terns (Sterna hirundo) and Ringed Kingfishers (Megaceryle torquata) on plastic bags. They also present pictures on their Fig. 3 on waterbirds feeding among huge amounts of rubish/plastics – in their Fig. 3, “F” they identified as ‘Bulbucus ibis’, whereas the correct identification is ‘Nyctanassa violacea’.

Obs: SampleSize and the Taxonomy account refeers to the number of necropsied birds for stomach contents. Latitude and Longitude from ‘Centro de Recuperacao de Animais Marinhos’ (CRAM) in Rio Grande municipality.

Obs: Latitude and Longitude located at Juquehy beach, which is the main case reported in this study (the individual that ingested a PFF face mask). 3M PFF facemasks are made out of synthetic material, thus assumed here as plastic interaction.

Author: Barbosa-Filho, RC

Therefore, we kept this reference as ‘unpublished’.

Author: Soares & Schiefler
Title: Reproducao de Larus dominicanus (Aves, Laridae), na Ilhota da Galheta, Laguna, SC, Brasil
Obs: The authors mention "a piece of shoelace" in a nest, which we considered valid. By the '90s, shoelaces could be made of synthetic material and/or, at least, the tip of the shoelace could have been made out of plastic. SampleSize defined as the maximum nests recorded at once, therefore subestimated (the authors do not report sample size, as it’s just a mention on nest materials).

Author: Nascimento et al.

Author: Bege & Pauli
Title: As aves nas ilhas de Santa Catarina—aspectos da ecologia, etologia e anilhamento de aves marinhas
Obs: As this study is sort of an ‘species account’, and they just mentioned the use of plastic by birds, we did not consider aspects of ‘taxonomy’ (analysed/not analysed). “Muitas vezes sao encontradas, nas proximidades dos ninhos, fios de nylon e pequenos frascos plasticos, provavelmente recolhidos da superficie do mar’ (pp. 40 – Fregata magnificens).

Author: Colabuono & Vooren
Title: Diet of Black-browed Thalassarche melanophrys and Atlantic Yellow-nosed T. chlororhynchos albatrosses and White-chinned Procellaria aequinoctialis and Spectacled P. conspicillata petrels off souther Brazil
Journal_Unpub: Book chapter – in Neves et al (Eds) REVIZEE
Obs: The same data were, subsequently, published in a a peer-reviewed journal (ID 19), therefore we did not include this reference in the analysis.
